data.text: You might hear two different stress patterns for this phrase: Are you ok? da-Da-da-DA?

data.text: That has a primary stress on the second syllable of 'okay', and a secondary stress on the syllable

data.text: 'you'. Or, you might hear: are you ok? Without the stress on 'you'. Both are fine. What's

translation.text: 'bạn'. Hoặc, bạn có thể nghe thấy: bạn ổn chứ? Không có sự căng thẳng về "bạn". Cả hai đều ổn. Cái gì

data.text: more important is that your unstressed syllables are short, and your words link together.

data.text: flare out a little, but not too much because we're not starting a stressed syllable. And

data.text: as in BOO vowel, are you. The lips will round some for this sound, though not as much as

data.text: diphthong, kk, -kay. The jaw has to drop a good bit for the first sound there, the tongue

data.text: ok? Are you ok? Notice that the pitch of the voice goes up. -Kay, -kay. That's because

data.text: it's a yes/no question, and those usually go up in pitch at the end. Are you ok? Are

title: How to Say "Are you okay?" American English Pronunciation
